Did you measure the melting point of your final product? It would be interesting to see how it compares to the literature value.

to get out even more of the impuritys we add activated charcoal  to the dissolved benzoic acid and do a hot flitration after letting it cook for 20min on reflux (dont let it boil over, its a mess). for the recrytalisation we only put the clear solution on ice to get it to below 10 degrees C (the colder the better, as long as it doesnt start freezing) and vaccum filtrate and wash it (with cold water) like you did but slower to prevent loss. yield is between 90-98% (depending on workquality) with a purtiy above 99.5%.

What I think you need to do is to calibrate your thermometer. You will need 3-4 high purity solids whose melting points you know. You already have one, benzoic acid. Using your thermometer, determine the 'indicated' melting points of the standards vs the known melting points. This gives you a graph you can use to adjust any indicated thermometer reading back to a more accurate temperature. Speaking of purity, have you thought of looking into zone melting? For thermally stable compounds, you can achieve some absolutely stunning purities.
